WHAT DID WESTERN CANADIAN PIONEERS EAT?

A QUESTIONNAIRE

(Instructions: Fill in as much of this questionnaire as you can and mail it to Saskatchewan Archives Office, Box 100, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask.)

Name: Mrs. Jessie Gibbiet
Address: Edmonton (Red Deer Homestead)
Birthplace: Summerside, Prince Edward Island

1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS

What year did you start housekeeping in Western Canada? 1907
Where did you set up housekeeping? Leslie Valley
Where had you been living before that? New Brunswick
For how many people did you prepare meals? 3
How far was it to your nearest store? 25-30 miles
How often could a visit be made to the store? once every three months
What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years? sugar, flour, butter, apples, blackstrap syrup, tea, coffee, dried fruit, molasses, spices

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS

What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? Five Roses
In what quantities did you buy it? 3-4 hundred
What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? $2.50
How much did you use graham flour?
Whole wheat flour?
Was flour milled locally? Yes
How far away? What year? 1923
What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats? $1.4
What other grain products did you use?
Cornmeal? Yes
Whole wheat? Farina?
Other?
Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? Sometimes
How did you grind it? Some mills ground by hand

   - 50 pounds

   - 50 pounds

10. Was flour called locally?
    - Yes

11. How far away? That year?
    - 25 miles

12. What was the price for a twenty pound bar of rolled oats?
    - $2.50

13. What other grain products did you use?
    - Cornmeal

14. Did you grind your own wheat for porridge?
    - Yes

15. How did you grind it?
    - With a hand mill

18. What year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in western Canada? 1947........ Give the menu. List those present and give their approximate ages at that time.

19. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details.

Yes, sometimes when the weather was cold and lots of snow, the trip to the store at Stanley would be postponed in hopes of mild spell. We would be out of control as would make candles from tallow and perhaps we would only have our own vegetables, meat (but with no sugar, tea etc.).

I remember the trip to the store at Stanley would be痛苦.

I hope my mind spells, we arrive by end of week.

We would make candles from tallies and perhaps we would only have our own supplies, must God will me again, etc. etc.
20. Mention any outstanding differences in the preparation of meals in the earliest days as compared with today.

Today there is more raw fruit and vegetables and we don't eat as much fat meat.
